author: _shemnon
content: I think algo type should be a distinct field rather than a byte in a blob.  What if we have more than 55 types? (maybe not in 10 years, but plausable in 100 years)  going to 56 locks us into a 256 cap, and allowing a free int allows for smantic meanings in the nubmers, such as using FIPS numbers like 204 (0xcc) for MLDSA and doing <algo><security category> would make useful things like 2042, 2043, and 2045 for the three key strengths of MLDSA.  (And key strengths will easily chew up algos, apart from curves and whatever happens with zk standards)

author: _shemnon
content: Also a nit, primary signature sould be last.  when processing bytes linearly you calc the hash then have the hash ready for the signature. That's why some FIPs formats have salt before the signature fields in signatures like Falcon.

author: txtiger
content: If we’d have algorithm sub-types, we could have each algorithm handle those subtypes, this’ll leave it up to the algorithm to decide how to encode subtypes. Also, once we do get to the 256 cap, it wouldn’t be all that hard to implement something along the lines of a pseudo-algorithm for extending the algorithm space to a uint16 or greater.

author: etan_status
content: yeah, the point being, that _changing_  a field to suddenly mean something else is breaking. so, just packing it into the ProgressiveByteList leaves open this design space. like, if we define it as a uint8, the reality will be that this will eventually become some magic, that then indicates that another location should be examined for more distinguishing factors xD

author: etan_status
content: but yeah, numbering scheme is obviously open. could also do a 3 byte fips/secp/256k1 prefix, many options
